messages.content: Given a specific lesson topic, age range or grade of the students, and a list of diagnoses, provide the following fields in a JSON dict, where applicable: 1. "modified_lesson_content" (modified lesson content), 2. "modifications" (modifications made specifically for each diagnosis), and 3. "references" (APA source references used for modifications).
Provide a lesson plan on graphing suitable for students with dyslexia and ADHD, for Kindergarten through Grade 2.

content.subject: Math - Graphing

modified_lesson_content.title: Graphing
modified_lesson_content.overview: This activity introduces graphing. The teacher guides students in developing questions, setting up a blank graph, interviewing other students, and filling in the graph with results.
objectives: Fill in the graph correctly with the data
Interpret the data using a teacher-created worksheet

activities.description: Brainstorm as a class a list of questions to ask other students. Write questions in math journals.

modifications.dyslexia: Use large, clear fonts and visual aids. Provide printed handouts of questions.
modifications.ADHD: Keep sessions short with frequent breaks. Allow movement during activities.

activities.description: Create a class chart with questions for graphing responses.

modifications.dyslexia: Use color coding and symbols to aid comprehension.
modifications.ADHD: Incorporate movement, such as allowing students to stand or move while working.

activities.description: Schedule a time with another class for students to ask questions and record answers.

modifications.dyslexia: Allow extra time and use recording devices for students who struggle with writing.
modifications.ADHD: Ensure structured and clear instructions. Allow extra time and use recording devices.

activities.description: Compile results on the classroom chart together.

modifications.dyslexia: Use visual aids, such as icons or pictures, alongside text.
modifications.ADHD: Involve students in active roles to maintain engagement.

activities.description: Use a teacher-prepared worksheet for evaluation.

modifications.dyslexia: Ensure worksheets have clear, simple instructions with ample space for responses. Provide one-on-one assistance.
modifications.ADHD: Break tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

modified_lesson_content.closure: Extend the activity by having students create individual graphs with three questions for family members. Keep the graph in the classroom and include questions about it in morning work.

dyslexia: Use large, clear fonts and visual aids.
Use recording devices for writing tasks.
ADHD: Keep sessions short with frequent breaks.
Maintain a structured environment with predictable routines.
Use positive reinforcement and minimize distractions.
Break tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

references: International Dyslexia Association. (n.d.). Dyslexia Basics. Retrieved from https://dyslexiaida.org/dyslexia-basics/
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2020). ADHD in the Classroom. Retrieved from https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/adhd/school-success.html
National Institute of Mental Health. (n.d.). Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder. Retrieved from https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/attention-deficit-hyperactivity-disorder-adhd/index.shtml
